reporting-org.narrative: Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

title.narrative: Biorefinery enzymes for renewable chemicals: from discovery to industrial applications

description.narrative: Biorefinery enzymes for renewable chemicals: from discovery to industrial applications

Integrated biorefinery for sustainable production of chemicals, fuels and polymers from renewable carbon sources (e.g., agro-industrial waste) is a promising strategy for securing energy and resources. In this GCRF-STARS application, the University of Sheffield will partner with the National Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (BIOTEC) to deliver a specialist training on Biorefinery enzymes for renewable chemicals: from discovery to industrial applications to targeted audience from ASEAN member states. BIOTEC is Thailand’s national research centre under the umbrella of the National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA), Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST). Sheffield-BIOTEC partnership was initiated in 2016, through a pump-priming financial support from the EPSRC GCRF QuickSpend Scheme awarded to Dr. Tuck Seng Wong (applicant). The training will cover the use of native or engineered enzymes for processes such as biomass pre-treatment, saccharification, fermentation, anaerobic digestion, biocatalysis and biotransformation. The team aims to deliver the training through a synergistic combination of biennial skill schools and e-learning. The objectives of the proposed training are: 1) Upskilling and developing early career researchers from Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines, who are currently working or intend to work in the field of industrial biotechnology (IB). 2) Providing a multi-faceted IB training, which incorporates theory, practice, computer-aided learning, site visit, social and networking. 3) Adding value to the Continual Professional Development programmes of regional industries, particularly those who are investing in biomanufacturing. 4) Strengthening ASEAN regional R&D in waste management and waste valorization. 5) Encouraging academic-industrial partnership and collaborations among ASEAN member states to turn trash to cash. 6) Stimulating and shaping a circular bioeconomy in ASEAN. 7) Creating opportunities to bring together all bioeconomy stakeholders in ASEAN to drive policy development. 8) Creating a platform for exchanging knowledge in biorefinery enzyme engineering and applications. In brief, this application aligns with three GCRF thematic priorities for developing countries, which are: 1) Sustainable livelihoods, economic growth through the circular bioeconomy. 2) Sustainable production and consumption. 3) Affordable and sustainable energy.
